verses.text: I am telling the truth in Christ, I am not lying, my conscience also bearing witness in the Holy Spirit,
verses.comment: Paul begins this chapter with a solemn affirmation, emphasizing his sincerity, confirmed by the Spirit.

verses.text: that I have great sorrow and unceasing anguish in my heart.
verses.comment: Paul’s deep anguish is for his fellow Israelites who have not accepted the Messiah.

verses.text: For I could wish that I myself were accursed and cut off from Christ for the sake of my brothers, my kinsmen according to the flesh.
verses.comment: Paul’s sacrificial love recalls Moses’ intercession for Israel (Exodus 32:32).

verses.text: They are Israelites, to whom belong the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the law, the worship, and the promises.
verses.comment: Listing Israel’s privileges, Paul points to corporate blessings given to God’s people throughout history.

verses.text: To them belong the patriarchs, and from them, according to the flesh, comes the Messiah, who is over all, God blessed forever. Amen.
verses.comment: High Christology: Paul directly identifies Jesus as God, echoing John 1:1 and affirming the divine nature of Christ.

verses.text: But it is not as though the word of God has failed. For not all who descend from Israel belong to Israel.
verses.comment: Paul distinguishes between physical and spiritual Israel, emphasizing the importance of being part of God’s true people.

verses.text: Nor are they all children because they are descendants of Abraham, but 'Through Isaac your offspring shall be called.'
verses.comment: Paul quotes Genesis, showing that lineage alone does not guarantee blessing, but God’s promise does.

verses.text: This means that it is not the children of the flesh who are children of God, but the children of the promise are considered offspring.
verses.comment: Spiritual inheritance surpasses physical descent; God’s promise is paramount.

verses.text: For this is what the promise said: 'About this time next year I will return, and Sarah shall have a son.'
verses.comment: Paul references God’s sovereign promise to Abraham and Sarah, underscoring divine initiative.

verses.text: And not only that, but also when Rebekah had conceived children by one man, our forefather Isaac,
verses.comment: Paul continues to show divine election in Israel’s history.

verses.text: though they were not yet born and had done nothing either good or bad—in order that God’s purpose according to election might stand, not by works but by him who calls—
verses.comment: The primacy of God’s initiative and calling is emphasized, preceding human works.

verses.text: she was told, 'The older will serve the younger.'
verses.comment: Reversal of societal norms through God’s sovereign choice.

verses.text: As it is written, 'Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated.'
verses.comment: This covenantal language indicates preference and blessing, not mere personal emotion.

verses.text: What shall we say then? Is there injustice with God? Certainly not!
verses.comment: Paul affirms God’s justice and challenges humans to trust His wisdom.

verses.text: For he says to Moses, 'I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion.'
verses.comment: God’s mercy is sovereign and not limited by human expectations.

verses.text: So then, it does not depend on human will or effort, but on God who shows mercy.
verses.comment: Divine mercy is foundational for salvation; initiative lies with God.

verses.text: For the Scripture says to Pharaoh, 'For this very reason I raised you up, so that I might display my power in you and that my name might be proclaimed in all the earth.'
verses.comment: Even opposition is used by God to reveal his glory and plan.

verses.text: So then, he has mercy on whomever he wishes, and he hardens whomever he wishes.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty is total, yet never unjust.

verses.text: You will say to me, 'Why does he still find fault? For who can resist his will?'
verses.comment: Paul anticipates objections about God’s justice and human accountability.

verses.text: But who are you, a mere human, to answer back to God? Does what is formed say to the one who formed it, 'Why did you make me like this?'
verses.comment: Echoing the prophets, Paul insists that creation cannot judge its Creator.

verses.text: Does the potter not have authority over the clay, to make out of the same lump one vessel for honorable use and another for common use?
verses.comment: Strong imagery of God’s creative authority and ability to assign roles or destinies.

verses.text: What if God, wanting to display his wrath and make his power known, endured with much patience vessels of wrath prepared for destruction,
verses.comment: God’s patience toward those opposed displays both justice and mercy.

verses.text: and in order to make known the riches of his glory to vessels of mercy, which he prepared beforehand for glory—
verses.comment: The eternal destiny of the faithful is presented as God’s purpose from the beginning.

verses.text: even us whom he called, not only from among the Jews but also from among the Gentiles?
verses.comment: Paul underscores the universal call and mission, foreshadowing the multi-ethnic people of God.

verses.text: As indeed he says in Hosea: 'Those who were not my people, I will call my people, and her who was not beloved, I will call beloved.'
verses.comment: Paul cites Hosea to show the mystery of inclusion into God’s family.

verses.text: And in the very place where it was said to them, 'You are not my people,' there they will be called 'children of the living God.'
verses.comment: Fulfillment of prophecy of spiritual adoption and the expansion of God’s covenant family.

verses.text: And Isaiah cries out concerning Israel: 'Though the number of the children of Israel be like the sand of the sea, only a remnant will be saved.'
verses.comment: The concept of remnant theology: God preserves a faithful group in every age.

verses.text: For the Lord will finish his work upon the earth, thoroughly and quickly.
verses.comment: God accomplishes His plan decisively; see also fulfillment in Christ’s saving work.

verses.text: And as Isaiah predicted: 'If the Lord of hosts had not left us offspring, we would have become like Sodom and been made like Gomorrah.'
verses.comment: God’s intervention preserves a holy community despite the threat of judgment.

verses.text: What shall we say then? That Gentiles, who did not pursue righteousness, have obtained it, a righteousness that is by faith;
verses.comment: A profound turn: righteousness is offered to those formerly outside the Law by faith.

verses.text: but Israel, who pursued a law of righteousness, did not attain to that law.
verses.comment: Attempting righteousness by works alone misses God’s saving purpose.

verses.text: Why? Because they did not seek it by faith, but as if it could be attained by works. They stumbled over the stumbling stone,
verses.comment: Christ is the cornerstone and stumbling stone, fulfillment of Old Testament prophecy.

verses.text: as it is written, 'Behold, I am laying in Zion a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense, and whoever believes in him will not be put to shame.'
verses.comment: Paul identifies Christ as the prophesied foundation in Isaiah, crucial for salvation—a call to unite around faith in Christ as the God-given cornerstone.
